Abstract
This note is on Lattman's paper (2009 Eur. J. Phys. 30 L41). It seems to us
that the direct unification of the quantum mechanics and the gravity theory (for
a black hole) by Lattman is in doubt.
text.body:
Lattman recently just presented a heuristic derivation of the Planck length by combining the
concepts of general relativity and quantum mechanics (Heisenberg uncertainty relation) [1].
His idea was that the Planck length is the dimension of a volume of space in which mass
fluctuations arising from the uncertainty principle are sufficient to create a transient black
hole. As Lattman mentioned [1], his treatment was not a rigorous derivation, but rather a
simple didactic device, suitable for presentation to undergraduates.
To help the relevant researchers as well as postgraduates understand the current status of
quantum gravity development which should be of pedagogical purpose, the present author
would like to make some remarks in the following. Note that, however, an intriguing
prediction of various theories of quantum gravity (such as string theory) and black hole
physics is the existence of a minimum measurable length. This has given rise to the so-called
generalized uncertainty principle, or GUP, or equivalently, modified commutation relations
between position coordinates and momenta [2]. It means that in a gravity field the Heisenberg
uncertainty relation should be replaced by the generalized uncertainty principle [3]
